text: For any of the horse racing traders, obviously things are always changing but have anyone else noticed 2022 to be unusual, profits lower than expected.

elements.text: For any of the horse racing traders, obviously things are always changing but have anyone else noticed 2022 to be unusual, profits lower than expected.

text: inplay is harder this year

elements.text: inplay is harder this year

text: I use more fundamental pre race models, but I’ve also seen a drop off since about November 2021, trying to figure out what has changed

elements.text: I use more fundamental pre race models, but I’ve also seen a drop off since about November 2021, trying to figure out what has changed

text: I've had a disappointing year to date also. Mainly on the TPD side though, one way or another the low hanging fruit have long gone from that. I assume that's about increased competition but I don't really know. I'm turning the corner on my other betting but only by significantly developing my bots, which I haven't done for some time.

elements.text: I've had a disappointing year to date also. Mainly on the TPD side though, one way or another the low hanging fruit have long gone from that. I assume that's about increased competition but I don't really know. I'm turning the corner on my other betting but only by significantly developing my bots, which I haven't done for some time.

text: This year about the same as last year for me so far, but definitely working to maintain where I am. I've got the feeling the last couple years in general has become more competitive for me (football, racing pre-play, racing in-play). Long term strategies not doing as well as they used to, backtests don't represent live trading as accurately as they used to, and new things that do work don't last long. No quantitative evidence for any of this though, just from my sole experience the last couple years.

elements.text: This year about the same as last year for me so far, but definitely working to maintain where I am. I've got the feeling the last couple years in general has become more competitive for me (football, racing pre-play, racing in-play). Long term strategies not doing as well as they used to, backtests don't represent live trading as accurately as they used to, and new things that do work don't last long. No quantitative evidence for any of this though, just from my sole experience the last couple years.

text: Yeah I am seeing the same, reduction in liquidity is the only answer I have to what I am seeing

elements.text: Yeah I am seeing the same, reduction in liquidity is the only answer I have to what I am seeing

text: I used to turnover quite a lot at low margin, especially in 2018/19, but I guess because of higher adverse selection I now have to lower my stakes and aim for more accurate models with higher margin, but overall less profit than back then.

elements.text: I used to turnover quite a lot at low margin, especially in 2018/19, but I guess because of higher adverse selection I now have to lower my stakes and aim for more accurate models with higher margin, but overall less profit than back then.

text: At least we had a good time during the good times!

elements.text: At least we had a good time during the good times!

text: I do feel for newer players. Albeit maybe they're the 'problem' and for them these are the good times.

elements.text: I do feel for newer players. Albeit maybe they're the 'problem' and for them these are the good times.

text: No regrets, thought you were retiring?

elements.text: No regrets, thought you were retiring?

text: Yeah I sort of am / was but I just really like having income.

elements.text: Yeah I sort of am / was but I just really like having income.

text: Yeah, I'm not really complaining. It's natural for competition to grow, but it's just a shame the market for opportunity isn't growing.

elements.text: Yeah, I'm not really complaining. It's natural for competition to grow, but it's just a shame the market for opportunity isn't growing.

text: I agree with Liam , the fundemental volume decline, which there are many reasons for is a big issue.

elements.text: I agree with Liam , the fundemental volume decline, which there are many reasons for is a big issue.

text: Definitely. January good, Feb and March flat, April loss. Some of it my own fault, some of it not but profits do seem to have dried up over last 3 months. Seriously considering that it may have to be the end for me unless I can turn it around

elements.text: Definitely. January good, Feb and March flat, April loss. Some of it my own fault, some of it not but profits do seem to have dried up over last 3 months. Seriously considering that it may have to be the end for me unless I can turn it around

text: You have only just begun in your journey DC!

elements.text: You have only just begun in your journey DC!

text: I know I am a new boy but I also do this full time now (whatever that means) and I can't see myself having the will to devote time to it if I have to get back on the 9-5 slog working for someone else

elements.text: I know I am a new boy but I also do this full time now (whatever that means) and I can't see myself having the will to devote time to it if I have to get back on the 9-5 slog working for someone else

text: Not giving up yet though

elements.text: Not giving up yet though

text: I've been running out of momentum and new ideas for a while now. I keep saying I just have a couple things left in the pipeline, but always keep adding one more when there's only one left!

elements.text: I've been running out of momentum and new ideas for a while now. I keep saying I just have a couple things left in the pipeline, but always keep adding one more when there's only one left!

text: Just more than a little concerned about the direction things seem to be taking

elements.text: Just more than a little concerned about the direction things seem to be taking

text: I'm in a very similar position <@USYQKE5HN>.

elements.text: I'm in a very similar position

text: This isn't new though. We've seen times like this before. You can make it through of you really want to.

elements.text: This isn't new though. We've seen times like this before. You can make it through of you really want to.

text: For me the question is more about whether I want to.

elements.text: For me the question is more about whether I want to.

text: I don't think I have developed anything new since mid 2021, damage limitation on my current strategies

elements.text: I don't think I have developed anything new since mid 2021, damage limitation on my current strategies

text: Yeah, I'm exactly like you <@UGV299K6H>. I want the income, but I can't decide if I can be bothered to grind on with new stuff I'm not that excited about.

elements.text: Yeah, I'm exactly like you
. I want the income, but I can't decide if I can be bothered to grind on with new stuff I'm not that excited about.

text: Nice to be sitting in a house that you own whilst you think about it though isn't it!

elements.text: Nice to be sitting in a house that you own whilst you think about it though isn't it!

text: When you guys who have made lots of profit for a long time say "new stuff" do you mean new ideas on the same markets you already specialise in, or branching out to other event types?

elements.text: When you guys who have made lots of profit for a long time say "new stuff" do you mean new ideas on the same markets you already specialise in, or branching out to other event types?

text: At least you have your art to switch over to which will take up your time. I don't have anything that really interests me at the moment.

elements.text: At least you have your art to switch over to which will take up your time. I don't have anything that really interests me at the moment.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Both for me. Cricket looks interesting, which would be new for me. But struggling for an angle at the mo.

elements.text: Both for me. Cricket looks interesting, which would be new for me. But struggling for an angle at the mo.

text: <@U4H19D1D2> You still have the pretend day job in the office?

elements.text: You still have the pretend day job in the office?

text: I do, contract now to keep things ticking over, 100% remote so can't complain

elements.text: I do, contract now to keep things ticking over, 100% remote so can't complain

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> personally I just mean new ways of doing the same stuff.

elements.text: personally I just mean new ways of doing the same stuff.

text: Having expensive hobbies has kept my motivation for betting up

elements.text: Having expensive hobbies has kept my motivation for betting up

text: What do you mean by ticking over? To kill time or to keep your CV in shape?

elements.text: What do you mean by ticking over? To kill time or to keep your CV in shape?

text: CV looks good, I am good friends with a few, work 1-2days a week and covers all of my living, makes betting risk free for me and allows me to push

elements.text: CV looks good, I am good friends with a few, work 1-2days a week and covers all of my living, makes betting risk free for me and allows me to push

text: Yeah, that's a good way to look at it.

elements.text: Yeah, that's a good way to look at it.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Part-time is a good way to go if you're not 100% sure. Assuming you can find a deal like that.

elements.text: Part-time is a good way to go if you're not 100% sure. Assuming you can find a deal like that.

text: Needs to be low stress and low thought though - I don't think I would have made betting work if I wasn't full-time giving it 100% focus. But that's just me.

elements.text: Needs to be low stress and low thought though - I don't think I would have made betting work if I wasn't full-time giving it 100% focus. But that's just me.

text: Personally, it is a tricky thing <@USYQKE5HN>. My weapon of choice and experience is C++ but the language has undergone massive changes. It was already complex but complexity is off the charts now and I have little enthusiasm for it anymore. I am a bit old to be taking a career change. Always at the back of my mind is the "gap" on CV that this lifestyle choice creates - even though it is not a gap, employers often view non-commercial experience as next to useless

elements.text: Personally, it is a tricky thing

. My weapon of choice and experience is C++ but the language has undergone massive changes. It was already complex but complexity is off the charts now and I have little enthusiasm for it anymore. I am a bit old to be taking a career change. Always at the back of my mind is the "gap" on CV that this lifestyle choice creates - even though it is not a gap, employers often view non-commercial experience as next to useless

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> did some C++ last yes, talk about painful, was coding in .net and the debugger is so darn slow,. code was twice as fast as my C# but they really do not make it easy.

elements.text: did some C++ last yes, talk about painful, was coding in .net and the debugger is so darn slow,. code was twice as fast as my C# but they really do not make it easy.

text: It is the "modern" C++ that I don't like. All this heavy reliance on templating makes code close to unreadable at times. Last place I worked as a C++ dev, there were coders who preferred to use 50 classes with functions that had a single line of code rather than a a few functions with 10ish lines of code. To me that is plain stupid but it seems a popular way of thinking now. I presume it is so that they can unit test code to death but I would rather take a career change than do that for a living. All my stuff is pretty much restricted to C++11 which for me is fine, but when trying to get a job again that is going to be a problem. I also have the problem that I had to endure C# and Windows in my last job at a betting firm so my CV looks a bit wobbly right now.

elements.text: It is the "modern" C++ that I don't like. All this heavy reliance on templating makes code close to unreadable at times. Last place I worked as a C++ dev, there were coders who preferred to use 50 classes with functions that had a single line of code rather than a a few functions with 10ish lines of code. To me that is plain stupid but it seems a popular way of thinking now. I presume it is so that they can unit test code to death but I would rather take a career change than do that for a living. All my stuff is pretty much restricted to C++11 which for me is fine, but when trying to get a job again that is going to be a problem. I also have the problem that I had to endure C# and Windows in my last job at a betting firm so my CV looks a bit wobbly right now.

text: This year about the same for me as last, but had a good month in April mainly TPD. Still love the challenge :smile:

elements.text: This year about the same for me as last, but had a good month in April mainly TPD. Still love the challenge

text: I guess it is you that took all my money then <@UQL0QDEKA> April has  been savage for me. I am lucky that I took the good advice that <@UGV299K6H> gave me a while ago and imcrease my base bankroll amount - otherwise I would have been cooked.

elements.text: I guess it is you that took all my money then
April has  been savage for me. I am lucky that I took the good advice that
gave me a while ago and imcrease my base bankroll amount - otherwise I would have been cooked.

text: ...always gotta keep enough float. Good for mental health too.

elements.text: ...always gotta keep enough float. Good for mental health too.

text: I would assume this all boils down to a lack of new "casual" bettors. This is what happens to basically any 0 sum game when you cut out the lowest layer. The strongest players will be affected with a delay, as they can still profit from the ppl in-between, but as those cant profit anymore they ll vanish and that way it creeps up to the top.

elements.text: I would assume this all boils down to a lack of new "casual" bettors. This is what happens to basically any 0 sum game when you cut out the lowest layer. The strongest players will be affected with a delay, as they can still profit from the ppl in-between, but as those cant profit anymore they ll vanish and that way it creeps up to the top.

text: For anyone newly in this position what's always worked best for me is to scale back betting, re-assess and look to drive up margin even if it appears to be at the cost of total profit. Long term you come out more robust and more profitable over all. Exactly as <@USYQKE5HN> describes above.

elements.text: For anyone newly in this position what's always worked best for me is to scale back betting, re-assess and look to drive up margin even if it appears to be at the cost of total profit. Long term you come out more robust and more profitable over all. Exactly as
describes above.

text: That sounds like a surviving strategy as you basically put yourself higher up the hierarchy. If no new players are introduced, i dont think this would solve anything in the long run though.

elements.text: That sounds like a surviving strategy as you basically put yourself higher up the hierarchy. If no new players are introduced, i dont think this would solve anything in the long run though.

text: I'm at about 50% of where I was last year, although last year did start unusually well (in play horses). Keeping strategies profitable has always been like spinning plates for me - I'm dashing about like a man on speed at the moment :man-running:

elements.text: I'm at about 50% of where I was last year, although last year did start unusually well (in play horses). Keeping strategies profitable has always been like spinning plates for me - I'm dashing about like a man on speed at the moment

text: I don't know <@U01DVUAE2G1> I've survived for quite a long run so far.

elements.text: I don't know
I've survived for quite a long run so far.

text: You can see why this is not a manual trading game anymore, Peter W and a few others manage to do it but psychologically it is not good for your health. And with the limits on how much they can put into the bank each month for under 25s at betfair coming into play they really are reducing new blood.

elements.text: You can see why this is not a manual trading game anymore, Peter W and a few others manage to do it but psychologically it is not good for your health. And with the limits on how much they can put into the bank each month for under 25s at betfair coming into play they really are reducing new blood.

text: <@UGV299K6H> probably because eventually new players were introduced and that may very well happen again. But an ecosystem like this one is doomed to fall apart if the lowest layer keeps getting smaller

elements.text: probably because eventually new players were introduced and that may very well happen again. But an ecosystem like this one is doomed to fall apart if the lowest layer keeps getting smaller

text: Yes <@U01335QG2G3> Q1 last year was quite an anomaly for me too. Really exceptional. Generally Q1 is the worst time though. That's another thing to bear in mind right now.

elements.text: Yes
Q1 last year was quite an anomaly for me too. Really exceptional. Generally Q1 is the worst time though. That's another thing to bear in mind right now.

text: Yeah all of those jumpers for bumpers things early 2021 were very nice

elements.text: Yeah all of those jumpers for bumpers things early 2021 were very nice

text: The thing is <@U01DVUAE2G1> there've always been new players coming in and (presumably) old ones dropping out, and there's always been reasons to think the good times are ending. I've been through a bunch of them as have others. If you want it, and you work for it then you can come through the down turns better than you ever were before. <@USYQKE5HN> and I are talking about running out of the will to do it, not saying that it can't be done.

elements.text: The thing is

there've always been new players coming in and (presumably) old ones dropping out, and there's always been reasons to think the good times are ending. I've been through a bunch of them as have others. If you want it, and you work for it then you can come through the down turns better than you ever were before.
and I are talking about running out of the will to do it, not saying that it can't be done.

text: If I was talking to a younger me right now I'd tell him not to stress, and above all not to rush.

elements.text: If I was talking to a younger me right now I'd tell him not to stress, and above all not to rush.

text: i wasnt really trying to say that this is the end, rather that current dips in profits are likely to boil down to a lack of new players. A lack of new players for a longer period usually is the end of such an ecosystem, but i didnt mean to say this would happen or is likely to happen.

elements.text: i wasnt really trying to say that this is the end, rather that current dips in profits are likely to boil down to a lack of new players. A lack of new players for a longer period usually is the end of such an ecosystem, but i didnt mean to say this would happen or is likely to happen.

text: Certainly volumes are down, but when I started betting people were saying the exchange was dying and they've kept on saying it ever since. One day those people will be right, but right now  it just looks to me like all the other times.

elements.text: Certainly volumes are down, but when I started betting people were saying the exchange was dying and they've kept on saying it ever since. One day those people will be right, but right now  it just looks to me like all the other times.

text: I really dont feel confident making any prediction on how overall volumes will develop in the coming years. However i do think that in order to keep them up eventually things like e-sports will need to become more relevant. Horse and dog racing are a dying breed in basically any place other than UK/IRE/AUS and even there i d be surprised if those sports were to see any substantial growth. Betting itself will exist as long as ppl enjoy randomness or are greedy :D

elements.text: I really dont feel confident making any prediction on how overall volumes will develop in the coming years. However i do think that in order to keep them up eventually things like e-sports will need to become more relevant. Horse and dog racing are a dying breed in basically any place other than UK/IRE/AUS and even there i d be surprised if those sports were to see any substantial growth. Betting itself will exist as long as ppl enjoy randomness or are greedy :D

text: I guess the next step is to build a company that sells "features" for the models that people want to do this stuff ... that way you are an intermediary, no matter their performance.

text: I think that's the point at which you risk transitioning from being a professional gambler (which is still a cool thing to be) to being an exploiter of false hope, which is a really shitty thing to be.

text: gross revenue higher for ’22 but higher rate PC this year so net flat to last year. having to deploy increasingly sophisticated research infra to capture edge but it is also clearly apparent that total scale is very constrained (for what I am doing). the biggest disappointment I have faced is lack of major scalability. i have been unable to crack football consistently (but trying). time management issues at play as well, baby on the way. <@U4H19D1D2> please make `flumine` for crypto.
